user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of connection_check_timedout:
```c
static bool
connection_check_timedout (struct MHD_Connection *c)
{
  const uint64_t timeout = c->connection_timeout_ms;
  uint64_t now;
  uint64_t since_actv;

  if (c->suspended)
    return false;
  if (0 == timeout)
    return false;
  now = MHD_monotonic_msec_counter ();
  since_actv = now - c->last_activity;
  /* Keep the next lines in sync with #connection_get_wait() to avoid
   * undesired side-effects like busy-waiting. */
  if (timeout < since_actv)
  {
    if (UINT64_MAX / 2 < since_actv)
    {
      const uint64_t jump_back = c->last_activity - now;
      /* Very unlikely that it is more than quarter-million years pause.
       * More likely that system clock jumps back. */
      if (5000 >= jump_back)
      {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
        MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
                  _ ("Detected system clock %u milliseconds jump back.\n"),
                  (unsigned int) jump_back);
#endif
        return false;
      }
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
      MHD_DLOG (c->daemon,
                _ ("Detected too large system clock %" PRIu64 " milliseconds "
                   "jump back.\n"),
                jump_back);
#endif
    }
    return true;
  }
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: MISRA C:2023 Rule 14.3 concerns invariant controlling expressions. To be conservative, I have reported every control statement (all if conditions) present in the function so they can be checked for invariance (including the nested conditionals). Other parts of the function do not need investigation under Rule 14.3: variable declarations (const uint64_t timeout, now, since_actv, jump_back) and arithmetic/assignments are not controlling expressions; return statements are not control expressions; comments and logging calls (inside #ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES) are not controlling expressions; there are no loops or switch statements in this function (so the rule's loop-related exceptions are not applicable here). Preprocessor conditionals (#ifdef) are compile-time directives and not subject to this run-time controlling-expression rule. Therefore only the listed if-condition fragments are relevant to check for potential invariant controlling expressions.
